ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES



Ruiz Food Products, Inc. is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety. This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program. This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at the Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility. 



It is the policy of Ruiz Food Products, Inc. to ensure that controls are in place to prevent possible releases of ammonia. If such a release does occur, the facility's emergency response personnel are trained to control and mitigate the effects of the release. The facility has coordinated emergency response activities with the Region 5 LEPC and the Dinuba Fire Department, who provide additional emergency response expertise.

  

STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE



Ruiz Food Products, Inc's primary activity is frozen food manufacturing. Located at 501 South Alta Avenue in Dinuba, California, the facility prepares, stores, and ships frozen food products. Ammonia is the only RMP-regulated substance at the facility, and it is used to provide refrigeration for the preparation and cold storage of various food products. The maximum inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 75,000 pounds.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS



The Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility is in full compliance with EPA's accidental release prevention requirements as defined in 40 CFR Part 68, the requirements for the California Accidental Release Prevention program (CalARP), the OSHA PSM requirements of 29 CFR 1910.119, and the EPCRA Section 302 notification requirements. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that are in place at the Dinuba facility. 



Process Safety Information 

Ruiz Food Products, Inc. maintains a detailed record of safety information

that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment specifications associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment and process. 



Process Hazards Analysis 

The facility has conducted comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the ammonia system are identified and effectively controlled. Checklists and the HAZOP methodology were used to carry out the process hazards analyses. The studies were undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in engineering and process operations, and will be revalidated at least every five years. Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner. 



Operating Procedures 

To further ensure that activities are safely conducted in the ammonia system, Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has developed written operating procedures to supplement the current on-the-job operator training. These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operation, normal shutdown and startup, and emergency shutdown and startup. This information is regularly reviewed and readily accessible to operators involved in the processes. 



Training 

Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has an on-the-job training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating process equipment are competent in the operating procedures associated with this equipment. Written procedures are used to enhance the on-the-job training. Refresher training is provided at least every three years. All training is documented and validated. 



Mechanical Integrity 

Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has a written maintenance program in place for preventative maintenance of all ammonia equipment to ensure continuing reliable and safe operation. Equipment maintained under this program include pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, emergency shutdown systems, controls, compressors and pumps. System maintenance is completed only by qualified personnel with training in maintenance pr

actices, including in-house personnel and contractors as needed. Specialized training is provided as needed to ensure maintenance personnel are fully qualified. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner. 



Management of Change 

Written procedures are followed at Ruiz Foods to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures. This ensures that process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification. 



Pre-startup Reviews 

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Ruiz Foods. These written review procedures formally ensure that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation. 



Compliance Audits 

Ruiz Foods conducts audits on a regular basis to verify that the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits will be carried out at least every 3 years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits will be undertaken in a safe and prompt manner. 



Incident Investigation 

Ruiz Foods promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could have resulted in a release of a regulated substance. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from occurring under similar situations. All reports are retained for a minimum of five years. 



Employee Participation 

Ruiz Foods believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort and has developed a written plan to implement this philosophy. Company employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident preven

tion issues and to recommend improvements. In addition, facility employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the RMP rule, particularly information resulting from process hazard analyses. 



Hot Work Permitting 

Ruiz Foods has developed a permitting procedure for all hot work conducted in the vicinity of the ammonia equipment. It documents that appropriate fire prevention measures have been implemented, and defines the work dates and scope of work to be performed. The permit is kept on site until completion of the work. 



Contractor Safety 

On occasion, the facility hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities. Prior to selecting a contractor, a thorough evaluation of the contractor's safety performance is carried out. Ruiz Foods has a strict policy of informing contractors of any known potential hazards related the contractor's work and the processes within the facility. Contractors are also informed of all procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.



Facility personnel receive annual training regarding the emergency procedures. In the event that an ammonia leak is discovered, the person nearest to the leak will alert any personnel in the immediate area who are unaware of the danger, maintenance personnel, and/or their supervisor.  Maintenance personnel will determine what procedures and personnel are necessary to remedy the problem.  All employees will evacuate to the emergency evacuation assembly area.  Emergency agencies will also be notified as necessary as outlined in the Emergency Response and Planning section of the CalARP Program.    



FIVE YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



EPA's RMP regulation defines "accident" as the following: 



"The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following:

?    On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (?68.42(a)); or

?    Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (?68.42(a))." 



An investigation into the facility's accident history during the PHA Revalidation study performed on May 8-9, 2014, revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia over the past five years (May 2009 - May 2014) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds in 24 hours or that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above. In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a release of ammonia, nor any releases or "near misses" that warranted an internal incident investigation.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



Ruiz Food Products, Inc. has developed a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials. The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas. 



The facility's emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced to ensure they are properly functioning.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within processes that would require a modified emergency response. 



The Ruiz Food Products, Inc. facility coordinates its emergency response plan with the Region 5 LEPC and the Dinuba Fire Department.
